abstract.text: Initiates a dragging operation from the view, allowing the user to drag arbitrary data with a specified icon into any application that has window or view objects that accept dragged data.

object to be dragged.

The location of the image’s lower-left corner, in the view’s coordinate system. It determines the placement of the dragged image under the cursor. When determining the image location you should use the mouse down coordinate, provided in
, rather than the current mouse location.
This parameter is ignored.
The left mouse-down event that triggered the dragging operation (see discussion below).
The pasteboard that holds the data to be transferred to the destination (see discussion below).
An object that serves as the controller of the dragging operation. It must conform to the
protocol and is typically the view itself or its
object.
A Boolean that determines whether the drag image should slide back if it’s rejected. The image slides back to
if

This method must be invoked only within an implementation of the
or
methods.
Before invoking this method, you must place the data to be transferred on
. To do this, get the drag pasteboard object (
), declare the types of the data, and then put the data on the pasteboard. This code fragment initiates a dragging operation on an image itself (that is, the image is the data to be transferred):
See the
, and
protocol specifications for more information on dragging operations.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A set of methods that supply information about a dragging session.
A set of methods that are implemented by the source object in a dragging session.
An object that contains information about an input action, such as a mouse click or a key press.
A high-level interface for manipulating image data.
An object that transfers data to and from the pasteboard server.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed the left mouse button.
Informs the receiver that the user has moved the mouse with the left button pressed.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Causes the view to maintain a private graphics state object, which encapsulates all parameters of the graphics environment.
Initiates a dragging session with a group of dragging items.
Converts the point from the base coordinate system to the view’s coordinate system.
Converts the point from the view’s coordinate system to the base coordinate system.
Converts the rectangle from the base coordinate system to the view’s coordinate system.
Converts the rectangle from the view’s coordinate system to the base coordinate system.
Converts the size from the base coordinate system to the view’s coordinate system.
Converts the size from the view’s coordinate system to the base coordinate system.
Initiates a dragging operation from the view, allowing the user to drag arbitrary data with a specified icon into any application that has window or view objects that accept dragged data.
Returns the identifier for the view’s graphics state object, or 0 if the view doesn’t have a graphics state object.
Locks the focus on the view, so subsequent commands take effect in the view’s window and coordinate system.
Locks the focus to the view atomically if the
method returns
and returns the value of
Locks the focus to the view atomically if drawing can occur in the specified graphics context.
Implemented by subclasses to respond to mnemonics.
Copies the visible portion of the view’s rendered image within a region and lays that portion down again at a specified offset .
Allows the user to drag objects from the view without activating the app or moving the window of the view forward, possibly obscuring the destination.
Returns a Boolean value indicating whether the view is being drawn to an environment that supports color.
Unlocks focus from the current view.
A window that an app displays on the screen.
A false value.
A true value.
Type to represent a Boolean value.
A point in a Cartesian coordinate system.
A two-dimensional size.
